title: HTML Entities
gp1: Reserved characters in HTML must be replaced with entities:
gp2: If you use the less than (<) or greater than (>) signs in your HTML text, the browser might mix them with tags.
gp3: Entity names or entity numbers can be used to display reserved HTML characters.
gp4: To display a less than sign (<) we must write: < or <
gp5: A commonly used HTML entity is the non-breaking space:
gp6: Another common use of the non-breaking space is to prevent browsers from truncating spaces in HTML pages.
wp1: A non-breaking space is a space that will not break into a new line.
wp2: Two words separated by a non-breaking space will stick together (not break into a new line). This is handy when breaking the words might be disruptive.
wp3: If you write 10 spaces in your text, the browser will remove 9 of them. To add real spaces to your text, you can use the   character entity.
wp4: Diacritical marks can be used in combination with alphanumeric characters to produce a character that is not present in the character set (encoding) used in the page.
